definition: Materials that naturally break down into non-toxic components via biological activity (microbes, fungi). Useful for reducing long-term landfill waste when biodegradation conditions exist.

A systematic technique to measure environmental impacts associated with all the stages of a product's life — from raw material extraction through materials processing, manufacture, distribution, use, repair and maintenance, and disposal or recycling.
A supply chain that designs for reuse, repair, refurbishment and recycling to keep materials in use and reduce waste.
The creative reuse of waste materials into products of higher value — e.g., using textile offcuts to create new fashion products with aesthetic or functional upgrades.
Cotton grown without synthetic pesticides and fertilizers; certified varieties meet standards such as GOTS which also cover processing and social criteria.
A leading standard for organic textiles that covers environmental and social criteria across processing, manufacturing, packaging and labeling.
A group of certificates focused on harmful substances in textiles. OEKO-TEX Standard 100 certifies products tested for substances harmful to human health.
Reprocessing of textile waste using mechanical means (shredding, re-spinning). Often degrades fiber quality; works best for certain fibers like cotton blends or polyester.
Converting polymers back into monomers or feedstock via chemical processes — potential to restore fiber quality and process mixed waste streams, though energy & cost intensive.
Design approach where materials are kept in continuous cycles (technical or biological), enabling perpetual reuse without waste.
The degree to which a product or system enables reuse, remanufacture, recycling or biological return — striving to keep materials and products in use.
Small synthetic fibers released from garments during washing that can end up in waterways and marine life; mitigation includes improved filtration, material choices and washing technologies.
A brand initiative to collect used garments from customers for reuse, repair, or recycling.
The practice of openly reporting sourcing, processing, and supply chain information — essential for traceability and consumer trust.
Dye processes that minimize water usage, energy consumption and toxic chemical discharge — examples include cold dyeing, digital printing, and dope-dyeing.
Polyester derived from recycled PET bottles or textile waste; reduces virgin feedstock demand but recycling quality and microplastic concerns remain.
Digital record storing a product’s material composition and lifecycle data to enable reuse, repair and recycling downstream.
Policy approach making producers responsible for end-of-life management of products — incentivises design for circularity.
Design technique that minimizes fabric waste when cutting garment patterns by creative paneling and layout.
Ensuring fair labor practices, safe working conditions and living wages in textile supply chains.
Measure of how long a garment lasts in regular use — designing for durability reduces the need for replacements and overall environmental cost.
Materials that biodegrade safely under industrial or home composting conditions — requires correct certification and disposal routes.
Recycling where the recovered material is reused to make the same product, preserving quality (e.g., glass-to-glass). In textiles, fully closed-loop is still emerging.
Amount of water used in the lifecycle of a product — includes irrigation, processing, dyeing and finishing stages.
